posts.name: Jackson Yoes
posts.cooked:
This season ended on a high note, with an incredible experience at Worlds, but it wasn't without its challenges. Initially, our Limelight 3G cameras stopped working properly when we switched to POE power injection via the VH radio, regulated by the VRM. After some troubleshooting, we discovered that switching to DC power directly via the limelight’s jacks resolved the issue for the remainder of the season.  

Before heading to regionals, we always conducted a thorough inspection, including testing the ground connection between the robot frame and the multimeter, only to hear the alarming beep signaling a short circuit in the robot. We systematically pulled fuses until we located the faulty PDH breaker related to the MPM, which finally silenced the alarm.  

Further investigation revealed a short in the Limelight 3G, likely due to a connection issue on its frame. We fixed it by isolating the camera with electrical tape and washers, hoping it would pass inspection. However, when we disassembled it later, we couldn’t spot any visible damage, though I’m not sure what exactly to look for besides signs of burned PCBs.  

When the replacement Limelight 3G arrived too late, we temporarily swapped in a new Limelight 4 with the Hailo upgrade, even though we were already planning an upgrade. This decision paid off during regionals, where the system performed well despite our previous issues.  

Eventually, we replaced the defective Limelight 3G, but oddities persisted. Sometimes, the limelight would flash rapidly, indicating detection of an AprilTag, yet remained inaccessible via its web interface. After multiple attempts to reset it, including cycling both the limelight and the robot’s radio, we learned that the RIO might only assign IP addresses temporarily, potentially causing delays in accessing the system.  

This recurring issue became a common challenge throughout the season, often requiring nothing more than a hard reset to resolve.  

During one regional, we discovered that enabling the Hailo upgrade improved the limelight’s ability to detect AprilTags, so we used it successfully in the next match. However, the upgrade also caused the odometry to stop updating, leaving us unable to align for scoring. Upon consulting with a CSA, we learned that the blue circles appearing around bolts might indicate the neural network’s attempt to narrow down potential AprilTags, highlighting areas where the model struggled. This experience led us to opt against relying solely on the Hailo upgrade for now.  

At Worlds, during inspections, the RI detected a short circuit in our Limelight 4. Tracing it back, we found the culprit: a damaged Ethernet cable. Removing it fixed the issue, though reinserting it reintroduced the problem, leaving us puzzled. Luckily, the short measured 34kΩ, which presumably satisfied the inspectors.  

This season left me determined to explore alternative solutions, such as switching to PhotonVision, after dealing with enough limelight issues to pull out my hair. While we never confirmed whether our issues were due to poor batches or user error, seeing other teams like 118 successfully using four LL4s without problems made me wonder if we just had a string of bad luck. Any theories on what went wrong would be appreciated!

posts.name: viggy96
posts.cooked: You're not meant to run the VH radio using a Voltage Regulator Module (VRM). You should power it directly from the power board. Then, assuming you've set the PoE jumper, it will passively transfer the power board voltage to the two marked PoE Ethernet ports.

posts.name: Fletcher
posts.cooked: The RoboRIO does not assign IP addresses. Instead, these are provided by a DHCP server located on the VH-109. It continues to assign addresses regardless of how long the device has been active.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: FIRST California | FTAA, CSA, A/V, and everything between.

posts.cooked: For not being able to view the feed, did you try setting up a static IP? Does it reproduce when rebooting Rio instead of performing a power cycle?

posts.name: Jackson Yoes
posts.cooked: Yes, I’m sorry I seem to have left that out of the post for some reason. We were not powering the VH radio using POE after the first LL3G had the shorting issue.

posts.name: Jackson Yoes
posts.cooked: Yes, that’s what I assumed. It doesn’t make sense why the roboRIO or the radio would stop giving out IPs. Still, it’s confusing why we cannot reach it. Appreciate the explanation!

posts.name: Jackson Yoes
posts.cooked: Yes, static IPs and hostnames were set. We couldn’t reach the device using its static IP address or hostname until after a restart. Additionally, the radio port wasn’t functioning properly, and we tested multiple cables confirmed to work without success. The issue appeared to be related to the limelight-left.local:5801 address, specifically the IP 10.54.54.14, based on our records. Rebooting the roboRIO didn’t resolve the problem.

posts.name: Fletcher
posts.cooked: This problem with Limelights occasionally not connecting to Ethernet has been an issue since the Limelight 2 model. Some users have resolved it by reimagining the device, while others required an RMA. The core issue appears to be that the Limelight fails to boot correctly and does not start the network stack, which is why the link lights on the VH-109 remain inactive. Therefore, it’s recommended to reach out to Limelight support for assistance.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: FIRST California | FTAA, CSA, A/V, and everything between.
